SENT.plain: We report a patient with longstanding Crohn's disease (CD) developing recurrent sepsis and impaired neutrophil function tests
His inflammatory bowel disease was controlled with local steroids and sulfasalazine with only short exposure to azathioprine
His blood counts remained within normal range, but the marrow showed mild dysplasia
Repeated cytogenetic examinations revealed trisomies 8 and 9, which are typical for therapy related myelodysplasia
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) study showed stable persistent trisomies, confined to the myeloid lineage, one year after discontinuation of sulfasalazine

The long-term use of immunodulating agents in patients with CD is not without risks, and early therapy related myelodysplasia might not be easily detected by blood count and morphology assessment alone
